text: Pours a clear amber color. Aromas of juniper/malts and a touch of citrus/berries. Flavor is a little different. I thought it would be more juniper tasting. A little berry flavor and some hop bitterness near the end.

SF5. Pours a clear orange amber, slight head. Slight bitter hop and tea aroma. Flavor is caramel malts, fairly rich, tea, faint coriander even though I dont think they used any. Not bad, but not my thing, touch too sweet.

Rating from 2011. Bomber from Total Wine. Pours a hazing iced tea brown with a thin white head. The nose is caramel sweet, juniper, light fruits. Taste is spice, light fruits, sweet boozy with a malty/rye background. Lighter mouth feel. Meh. 2.9

From notes. Tasted on 11/12/11 from a capped 22oz bomber bottle. Pours clear bright orange with a thick white head that slowly recedes to average, spotty lace. The nose is a lot like a nice resin hoppy IPA with additional juniper and candied orange peel. The flavor starts off with a touch of caramel malt up front, moving to standard resin hops, finishing with some candied orange and herbal juniper. The body is medium with lively carbonation and a long herbal juniper finish.
i like the Juniper here more than I do in most beers, but overall this was just a so so sweetly spiced beer that was a little overpriced. NB makes better.

Big thanks to Mora2000 for hooking me up with this brew. Pours dirty light brown with sediment floaters. Nose is toffee and light juniper. Tastes of caramel, oranges, tea, Christmas wreath, lemon peel, and dried fruits. I imagine that the juniper has faded or this was always subdued. Sweet finish slightly chalky mouthfeel.
Bottle pour. Copper with small head. Nose is malt forward. Cinnamon, molasses. Candied fruit. Taste folds in juniper. Light bodied and dry.
Hazy amber colored pour. Small off-white head. Little bit of lacing. Very malty aroma. Notes of molasses. Taste is a very muted malt with some piney notes. Sweet and peppery.
Poured a light golden color with aromas of juniper, light fruit and some caramel. Flavors are the same interesting style, interesting beer... not sure about this one.

Bottle at the 14th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering on 03/19/2011 courtesy of Butters. Clear copper body with a small white head. Sweet fruit and caramel aroma with light spice. Sweet fruit and caramel flavor, light spice and citrus. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

From notes verbatim on 10/21/10

A: Apricot color with excellent clarity. low/no head formation.

S: More malt than anticipated. Cinnamon, peppercorn. Nothing special.

T: Touch of astringent on initial touch with hints of alcohol, juniper. Its like watered down gin.

M: Nice feel. Medium body with lower carb. Feels good.

D: No thanks.

Serving type: bottle

03-07-2011
Poured from a 22 ounce bottle. This pours malty, slightly spicy. A nice malty beer. Not much spice character.
Weird beer. Rye and Juniper are apparently not my thing... Especially not the Juniper in this one. To much, to messy, not for me.

Bottle.  This smells faintly of caramel and malt and pours a pale amber.  It tastes faintly of citrus and strongly of sweet malts.  the hopping is very subtle.  Its an interesting brew to try but not one I would take on regularly.

Bottle: &nbsp Amber with an orangish hue, dirty orange as its hazy, moderate frothy sandy head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Very shrubby nose, slightly sweet & sour, like an unripe huckleberry. &nbsp Has a bit of Juniper too. &nbsp Candyish maltiness up front, dull Juniper, with a soft high alpine shrubby sort of background. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp It seems to stick to the tongue rather well. &nbsp Just so you know, I sat on this bottle for a while. &nbsp Nothing about this beer (being aged) is bright, but its very mellow and well melded. &nbsp Its a little different, and could use a bit more sweetness to balance the shrubby dryness. &nbsp Meh, its interesting enough to keep sipping at least.

Pours a copper/amber color with slight carbonation to it. Scent is that of sweet malts and spices. The taste is rather smooth and similar to a good Oktoberfest beer. Plenty of good spice taste. A great brew and worth of being a $6 beer. Being a limited time deal, I had to try it!

22 oz. bottle from Randalls. Got this one in 2010 when I bought a couple other takes on this style. This one pours a mostly clear, lighter orange color with a bit of cloudiness and a moderate off-white head. Aroma of juniper, crackery malts, lemon peel, and straw. The flavor is pretty much the same; dry malts and juniper, mostly. Light-bodied, with a dry, earthy mouthfeel and low carbonation. My first crack at the style and it was decent.

Pours a slightly murky gold color with pretty much no head. Aroma is sweet with both some lighter citrus fruit notes as well as some darker fig and prune types. The taste is similar with only a little bitternes. The fruit flavors are very rounded; they start somewhere and then continue to develop until they eventually arrive back where they started. Pretty good beer.

1/9/2011 - New Belgium brewery has never had the boisterous volume of breweries like Stone. Their brewery is amply proud of its mission to be green in its pursuit of brewing, but I hear comparatively little bragging about some of their finest creations - the Lips of Faith series. Thats why the Sahti fits their personality so well. A deep bronze color and mild carbonation with a head quick to evaporate dresses a light, soft, mildly spicy and demure beer. I found honeysuckle and light malt aromas in the nose, and a soft and soothing carbonation pairs nicely with the subtle flavors of all spice and cinnamon. I would enjoy this more if the flavor profile was turned up a little but, but I can also appreciate when a beer chooses to be an off-note in an otherwise loud and complicated song.
Orange pour with a white head.  Its fruity and malty and its ok, but isnt that grand.
Night of the Lips of Faith series continues to dissapoint.  This is just oddly grassy and wierd.  I cant even describe the watery subtle flavors in here.  Maybe light sea weed and bark?  bad
Some light tea flavors. Lightly sweet. Kinda boring and nothing else going on. But hey, nothing is better than terrible
bottle - Pours clear orange with a small off-white head and a fruity, malty aroma. Its sweet and fruity with a faint hint of juniper and a touch of hops in the finish. Its alright.
pours a pale gold, malt and tea aroma. Thick body, lots of tea and juniper flavor. Pretty good all around beer

Hazy amber colour. Small white head. Gently malty aromas. Notes of biscuits and caramel. Slightly oxidized. No noticeable rye nor any juniper, so it is hard to tell why they call it a sahti, for it does not appear like one. That said, it is a pretty tasty beer.

Pours a translucent orange-green with a fast fading thin white head. Aroma is spicy, fruity, rye, bread, some bitter citrus.Taste is very mild, very nice up front; bread, earth, yeast. The flavors become somewhat generic however. Not much character in the middle. The finish is bitter, but again, rather general in flavor and character. Not bad, not great; a step up from okay.

This feels like an incredibly well-made MACRO-brew. I feel like it would make a GREAT gateway beer for someone who only drinks Busch Light.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 
Name: LoF Sahti
Date: December 28, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Hop City, Atlanta
Appearance: clear copper, wispy off white head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet and very spicy aroma, fruity sweetness
Flavor: sweet and fruity flavor, candy caramel, balancing spicyness, light bitterness
Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4
bomber pour that comes out golden colored. aroma of citrus zest, juniper and hops. taste that follows the aroma. the citrus and juniper stand out. different for sure but not half bad.

Pours light amber with a large off-white head. Smells a bit like rye, some earthiness, and a touch of juniper. Tastes bitter, a bit funky, kinda citrus peel spiced, juniper notes. Medium-bodied with a slick texture and active mouth-carbonation, New Belgium Lips of Faith Sahti finishes funky.

Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Beautiful, clear golden-amber color with thin white head. Pleasant aroma of grain, hops and subtle juniper. Restrained malty sweetness, some rye crispness, slight biscuit taste. Nice round mouthfeel, very dry finish. Heres the thing: I know talk of "beer styles" makes the New Belgium brewers skin crawl, and I like that about them. But hey, they called this Sahti, not me, so I feel entitled to quibble. Sahti is an ancient Finnish style using rye as most of the grainbill, mashed with and lautered through a juniper twig bed, not boiled, utilizing little or no hops, fermented with rough bakers yeast, left unfiltered. This beer doesnt appear to use much juniper or rye, is clearly boiled with hops, fermented with a very refined neutral yeast, and microfiltered. Its a great beer, possibly better than most Sahtis, definitely more shelf-stable, but it barely resembles true Sahti. Regardless, you should give it a try.

(draft 12/28/10). Clear deep gold color. Medium off white head. Light grass and citrus hop aroma. Same flavor, with light sweetness and light bitterness. Avg duration. Light bitter finish with light alcohol. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

22oz bomber from Pinch poured into an English Pint. Pours a dark burnt orange with a small bit of off-white head. Slight aroma of sweet malt and citrus hops. Medium sweet and light bitter. Medium bodied with a creamy yet oily texture. Lively carbonation and a long sweet finish. Overall, not bad. Nothing I would seek out but something I would drink again.

Hazy orange amber under a bright white head that thinned and dissipated in short order. The aromas didnt smack of juniper as I had expected, but were rather subtle and leaned more toward blood oranges. The flavours are the main writing point as it was sweet and tangy with orange citrus flavours. It was a fairly light beer considering its pedigree (and its alcohol content, thought my companion who si a very learned chap in these matters). The hop content was either incredibly subtle or my tastebuds had taken a beating from dinner. Juniper cames through on a subtle note toward the finish as well as being herbal and astringent with lots of ginger. 
This beer was ideally suited to its purpose as a mid-dinner conversation piece. Plenty to muse on and good dollops of flavour to accompany the strength of the Mexican dishes we were eating. A cracking drop.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into dimpled mug.

Appearance: Clear amber with thin white head that disappears leaving no lacing. I thought a Sahti should be cloudy?

Aroma: Bready with a decent level of spiciness, citrus and a somewhat metallic bitterness (this may be the juniper).

Taste: Very bready, caramely and spicy, with citrus and juniper. The juniper just seems a little strange to me, as if some gin was poured into my beer. Surprisingly simple, and almost ordinary, compared to my expectations.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium body with a juniper-driven dry finish. Strangely boozy for the moderate alcohol.

Overall: Hard to review a style I have not had before. It is hard to know if it is indicative of the style or not. My guess is not, since I thought it would be much more yeasty, both in appearance (cloudy) and in taste (banana, maybe slightly tart). As is, this seems to be simple English Ale with a bunch of juniper. I will need to try one of the better reviewed examples of the style to know if I am the problem or if the beer is (I have a sneaking suspicion it is the beer).

22 ounce bottle shared by Butters at the 14th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 3/19/11. Pours a clear golden color with a thin head that fades quickly. Aroma of pale wheat malts, nutty notes, herbal notes. The taste is sweet malts, herbal notes, citrus and caramel. Fairly sweet. Medium bodied. Decent.

22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small white head.  The aroma is a battle between juniper and other herbs and the sweet caramel malts that try to take over.  Some vegetal notes with agitation.  The flavor is sweet caramel malts, light leafy notes, juniper and a touch of spicy rye.  I get some sweet tea toward the finish.  This was strange and I probably wouldnt have this again.

22. Pours a somewhat hazy bronzed medium amber with a loose and thin tan head. Drippy lace. Bit heavy-handed with the caramel on the nose, almost like a candy bar melting in the sun. The juniper and rye just emphasize the sweetness of all the residual sugars in this. Creamy medium body with prickly carb, though not much of it. That gin flavor juniper, along with the spiciness of the rye, kick up a little on the mid palate, flowing under the river of malty caramel notes. You can almost feel the angry little imprisoned sugar molecules trapped in this beer, slashing rebelliously against your mouthflesh on their way to their doom, its just sharp and prickly and coruscating. Overbearing and oversweet.

Opens up with a one finger head that pretty much disappears by the time I walk to the other room. Clear amber colored body. Orangy aroma. Juniper comes through in the flavor, as does the rye backbone. Cascade hops sure are nowhere to be found. Bit of a "twang" in the back end. Definitely worth trying, especially for those that like non-traditional beers.

Poured into a tall flute.

The pour is a soft orange yellow with some soft head produced.

the aroma is very minimal, not a whole lot of much.... some sweetness and some very minimal hop presence.

the taste is almost non-existent. upfront the is a weird bland american ale taste to it. Sort of mild hops with a little sweetness and almost no juniper presence. The is almost nothing on the mid or back palate... just falls right off.

it is an easy drinker for sure... but i am a bit let down by this beer.

not great for taste or for the sahti style.

22 oz. bottle.  Medium orange pour with a small white head.  Aroma of some bread dough, crackers, some spruce and citrus peel.  Flavor is doughy with some spice, juniper,  and spruce.  Vegetal plants, citrus.  The more I drink this the more it tastes like a spiced version of fat tire.  Blegh.  Thin to medium bodied.  I feel like this fat tire ale base gets dragged out way too often by New Belgium.  Wouldnt ever buy or drink this again.
Bottle. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy hoppy aroma. Sweetish malty fruity spicy caramel flavor with hoppy hints. Has a sweetish malty spicy warming finish.

Medium offwhite head. Hazy deep yellow body. Fruity resiny papery aroma with herbal notes. Dry-sweet resiny spicy cinnamon taste with honeyish mealy notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mealy mouthfeel. Dry resiny honey aftertaste with mealy fruity notes. Nice, but a bit old, and nothing at all to do with sahti. (0.65l bottle, Café Amsterdam, San Francisco.)
I didnt think that this was particularly junipery. Some spices a little sweet. Slightly oily mouth feel but not in a bad way. I have to say I kind of liked it. Serving: Bottle
out of bottle, this beer was light and crisp with some peppery spiciness to it probably wouldnt go out of my way to get this one again, but fun to try

Bottle. Poured a clear copper color with an average white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate aroma of citrus, leaves and earthy. Medium body with smooth dry texture and soft carbonation. Medium citrus bittersweet flavor with a medium complex bitter sweet finish of moderate duration. Interesting complex brew.

22 ounce bomber.  Ive seen this several times but never picked one up, until last night.  Im not really sure what to expect out of this beer.  The label states its a Finnish Rye and that its got some hops in it.  Little to no head, cloudy appearance, murky carbonation.  Color is a nice amber brown, cinnamon.  Aroma isnt as big as I had hoped for  guess those hops arent used for aroma.  I can pick out the rye and some caramel malt sweetness.  Pretty disappointing really.  Luckily the beer makes up for it in the taste department, as theres lots of things going on.  The spice of the rye really hits you first, it kind of punches you in the mouth and makes you sit up and take notice.  Unfortunately, from there things sort of wash out in the middle, as the mouth is still reeling from the initial hit of rye.  However the beer makes a comeback, finishing with floral juniper and citrusy hop bitterness.  This is clearly and almost makes up for the lack of complexity in the middle.  Mouthfeel is sufficiently slick though never oily, with medium carbonation.  Its somewhat watery  I find myself wanting the body of the beer to be a little bit heartier.  Theres a little bit of a hint of alcohol esters in the middle of the beer but nothing outlandish  and Im relatively sensitive to those so you may not even notice.  Overall this is an interesting though slightly disappointing beer.

Picked this up at the Liquor Stop in Indiana. Shared at a recent tasting and poured into a tulip.

Really not a good example of a Sahti. Oh well, here goes. The beer pours a moderate golden color with a thin white head with moderate retention. The nose brings forward a bit of bready malt. Really plain. Plain, plain, plain. How does that happen with a sahti? Normally Im complaining that theres way too much going on. The taste is along the same lines. A bit of mild weirdness from who knows what in the background, but mostly just a bit of lightly-sweet malt. Feel is medium and average. Decent carbonation. Nothing horribly offensive about this beer, its just a bad example of the style. It just doesnt really present anything that would make me think this was a sahti.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-04-2011

Bottle. Pours gold with a brown tinge; head looks so solid that it could be blown insulation. Nose has spicy and juniper notes atop roast and toast. Definite juniper on the tongue as well; also some hops bitterness and spicy notes, over an underlay of malt; I dont get the citrus in the description anywhere. Mouthfeel is very round -- almost too much so. Good, but not something Id drink a lot of.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured gold with a thin white head.  aroma was grain, candy sugar??, and spice.  flavor matched the aroma with a light body.

I poured a 22 oz bomber into my glass mug...

The liquid was an orange, amber color with a bubbly white head that dissipated quickly. The smell is a bit funky, with hints of sour orange juice and other floral aromas. The taste consists of rye, honey, citrus, biscuits and some spice in the aftertaste. The beer is medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a wet finish. Honestly, I did expect more out of this beer. I was looking for Vrienden but they were out, this is still a good and interesting beer.
After being wowed by Le Terroir, had my hopes up for this one.  Must say I was let down.  Juniper, not tasting it.  Citrus, not tasting it.  Medicinal and alcoholic.  Boring.  Looks pretty though.

Comes out of the bottle a lovely clear amber with a thick, white, fine-bubbled, fairly persistent head. Aroma is strong, yeasty and spicy with fruity and malty hints. Flavor has a strong spicy tone, mainly cloves, and also some woody hints along with a malty undertone and fruity and yeasty tones. Texture is rather ragged and fizzy, leaving behind a nice spicy tingle.

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into my New Belgium glass 57°. The color is a nice amber, with a decent white head that the etching kept nicely. The aroma is very complex on this one. Rye malt comes through, along with citrus aromas from the orange, lemon and juniper. Mouthfeel is full bodied, and average carbonation. Flavor is fantastic! Im a fan of a good rye anyways and this is way above good! Flavour starts with a mild hoppiness from the Cascade and Amarillo hops, then transitions to the nice smooth rye malt sweetness that lingers around with a nice finish that is not too dry. Overall this is a very balanced beer with lots of complex aromas and flavors that you and your friends will enjoy!! I will probably try to clone this in my home brew! Also burps really nice, with a citrusy, sweet kind of burp...

Smells fresh and malt-hoppy. Very attractive pour. Aside from the rye I honestly could not appreciate or sense the rest of the promised ingredients, so maybe should have scored a little lower, but I still appreciated it as a tasy well balanced complex (though non-distinct_ ale.

Pours clear golden with a thick off-white head and a toffee aroma. There is a puckeringly dry rye flavor with some spices, mostly juniper. Leaves a dry medicine-like taste on the palate. Unique, but not all that tasty.

[Tap] Pours a dark shade of gold with a slight amount of haze and an average looking head. Dried spices and grains in the nose. The taste is of mild rye malts, floral and grassy notes, some orange peel and herbs. The palate was a little light, but probably not too bad for the style. High carbonation level with large bubbles. Interesting to try, but actually this was more bland then I thought it would be.

22oz bottle poured into an English Pint at 53°.  Color is a golden amber with good carbonation and a soft white head.  Aroma a sour wet cut wheat and rye scent.  Medium body with a creamy mouth feel.  Flavor comes in malty with the rye standing out then some lemon and honey.  After taste is cloddy and bland as the flavors meld together and just hang heavy  in your mouth.  I do not like it, the only good thing I can say is thank god you cant taste the juniper.

22oz bottle 3/23/11 (Veteran Liquor) 58° in Dimpled Mug-Pours a mediu, golden amber with a decent off white head. Aroma of malt, rye, and wet wheat. Taste of rye, malt, lemon, and honey. This medium bodied brew is not bad but not my cup of beer.

22oz bomber.  Glowing orange-tan.  Thin off-white head.  Interesting aroma..honey, spruce, ginger, clove.  Comes off a little big and malty, whereas the only Finnish example I had was somewhat tart and tangy under a soft body.  This is a little more thick and rich, and while there is some obvious herbal flavor, it doesnt quite balance out the sugary malt tones.  The lemon and orange peel show, sort of like the Sahtea but way less impressive.  Not bad by any means, just not quite living up to the high standards of other Lips of Faith beers.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, almonds, and some juniper.  Poured amber/orange in color with a small, off-white/tan head that diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer, as well as around the edges.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Average lacing.  Flavor is slightly sweet.  Tastes of malt, light almond, slight hops, slight coriander, and juniper berries.  Medium body.  Slick, slightly oily texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, malt, slight hop, and slight juniper finish.  Not very good at all.

Bottle courtesy of ughsmash.  Pours copper with a thin head.  Smells of bananas, cloves, earthy, breaddy.  Tastes of pine, tea, earthy, lightly spicy with some earthy hints on the finish.  Good beer in its own right, but not true to the style.

Date: 3/19/2011   Source:Butters   Light graininess with earthy hops in aroma. Clear deep golden with small white head. Malty with spicy earthy hops. Quite bitter which balances the malt sweetness. Medium body and mouth feel with touch of warming. Finish is dry medium sweet and warming.
Sampled at the Richmond 14th Gathering. Clear golden pour.  Honey, ginger, a little hot on the nose, floral and herby. Refreshing. Good, not great.  But different.

Pours a dark orange with very minimal head. Aroma is nothing compared to the other two Sahtis Ive had.  Dont get really any of the juniper/earthy aroma present in past beers.  The aroma is more along the lines of Carmel and orange with a big spice base.  The beer itself is very malt forward with out much going on.  Sweet toasty malt, marmalade, and some spices.  No real twigs, earthiness, or juniper.  Short, easily forgettable finish.  Good effort, but there are way better Lips of Faith beers.
A lot of it reminded me of fat tire, especially the malts, the juiper and spices saved it a bit.

22 oz bottle

Sahtis are one of those styles that set the great brewers apart from the rest. It takes a delicate touch to make a beer that has some character but isnt a slap in the face. Of the few I have tried this one is not my favorite. However it does meet all the criteria of a solid beer - a reasonable price point, some unique qualities, and a range of flavors to please most palates. I am already looking forward to my next bottle in the Lips of Faith series.

Aroma / Appearance - Lively carbonation is evident through the light bronze body. Looking like a sparkling wine it seems as if the bubbles are desperate to escape. Spiced herbal tea is light and airy with a good balance of hops. Red berries and hints of fig give this a nice seasonal air.

Flavor / Palate - Full bodied and robust the mouthfeel is thicker than I expected. A mix of floral and woody hops it glides carelessly down the throat. Mellowing out within seconds it manages to still leave a calling card of fig and roses. A distinct change of pace from your run of the mill IPAs, stouts, and pale ales this was a bold experiment that succeeded. Hopefully other breweries and brewpubs will give the style a shot in the future.

Bomber.  Pours orange hazy hue... not much foam.  Aroma is barnyard funk, fruit (peaches?) and some faint spice...  Taste is refreshing, or maybe Im just THAT thirsty.  Starts out spicy and tangy, then turns more bitter as the grapefruit peel taste sneaks in, before a final turn toward pepper finishes things off.  ABV well-disguised enough.  Big issue here is that the beer is nothing all that original.  Its a decent seasonal.  Nothing more.

22 ounce bottle - $5.49 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, amber-hued body with a two finger-high, whitish head.

Smell: Sweetish, grainy nose, smelling of malted barley with a hints of spicy rye, golden syrup, peppery alcohol, and juniper-scented soap.

Taste: Toasted barley and a zip of rye with a caramel-like sweetness and hint of crushed sugar cookies. Slight hint of juniper berries. Light kiss of citrus. Somewhat soapy character midway, picking up warming alcohol nearing the end. Dry finish with a bit of displeasing medicinal twang to it.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A letdown, really. The loosely medicinal, booziness of the brew, along with its ho-hum flavor, leaves me a bit flat.
Courtesy of thirdeye11. Clear dark amber color/ no head. Toasted caramel, mild spicy aromas. medium bodied. Sweet caramel, white bread, mild sweet spice flavors.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: nice amber pour. nose is flowery. flavor is interesting. is to style but notas interesting as others i have had

22oz bottle.
Aromas of sweet, spicy malt.  Bit of an herbal flavor - floral hops.  Not a fan of this one.

22 ounce bottle purchased at Nugget in Woodland, CA.  The aroma on this is very estery with plenty of fruity notes.  A little banana.  Virtually no smokiness or juniper berries present.  Definitely not what I have experienced with previous sahtis.  Seems more like a Belgian ale.  Transparent orange body with a small, quickly dissipating whitish head.  Starts a little sweet, before this becomes chewier, and stickier in the middle with some yeasty ester flavors.  Good deal of banana is there.  Finishes lightly herbal and lightly bitter.  This lacks many of the traditional aspects of a real sahti.  Disappointing.  This tastes more like a Belgian ale/Biere de Garde than anything else.
Slight hazy amber in the glass. Fruity aroma with a touch of sweet malt. Subtle spicy flavor with a sweet malty palate.

22 oz. bomber
Appearance:  Pours a dark orange, fairly clear with no head.

Aroma: Soft vanilla and chamomile.

Taste: Chamomile, spice, small bitterness. Flavors fade to nothing.

Mouthfeel: High carbonation, thin mouthfeel.

Overall: I was not impressed with this beer at all. On paper, it sounds delicious, I was just dissapointed, as I was looking for more.

Kens bottle.Light orange with carbonation bubbles, two inch head.  Funky and malty aromas.  A spicy taste, with some pine and spruce.  A smooth mouthfeel.  Sweet, then a bitter finish with mint aftertaste.  I am not the biggest fan of Juniper.  Lacey.  Drying.
On tap at New Belgium hub at DEN.  Pours amber brown, with thin head.  Some slight citrus aroma but didnt get much else.  Slightly sour taste with fair amount of tounge feel, a dry hoppy finish.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a fair amount of head.  Nice light spicy malty flavor with a quick finish.
Draft sample at KC FS. Clear, light gold color with no real head. Light aroma of slightly sour grain. Very herbal, rich, and tea-like flavors. Maybe not my style.

Bomber.  Nose is vaguely sweet malt, has a juniper and spruce aroma that reminds more of perfume than anything woodsy.  Intense and room-filling (not on HOTD levels, though).  Pretty clear amber pour with a short beige head.  Am I deceived, or do I detect some significant hop bite?  A little rushing, gritty graininess over the occasionally syrupy malt, which itself settles down to be somewhat flat.  Juniper comes through more, and its distinctly on the berry side.  Bit of a toothpaste experience, the flavors leading in the direction of cool, soothing mint are pleasing enough but then theres that gritty cleansing aspect.  Deft touches of flowers and honey, with faint peppery smack.  Some lesser caramel and stale air, mild vanilla and some genuinely interesting malt depth, spice is toned down but still atop the earth.  Overall, hard to get excited about recommending this one, but Ive certainly enjoyed the first glass.

Pale, clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of citrus, pine, grass and dough. Taste is sweet with a little bit of a dry hoppy background. It tastes ok, but theres nothing special to it.  Body is fairly light and a bit refreshing.

Pours clear amber with a medium beige head, very fine clinging lacing.
Aromas of biscuit, grass, caramel, juniper, and grapefruit.  Medium body, zesty, crisp, lightly dry.  Medium sweet, barely any tartness, with a medium bitter, peppery finish.  Drinkable but mild.

From a 22 oz bottle this poured a clear orange with a minimal white head and almost no lacing.  Nose of citrus and pine. Medium body and mild mouthfeel. Favor of light citrus . Light finish.  While there was not a lot going on here it was easy drinking.

750ml bottle. Dark amber pour with thin bubbly head. Malty aroma with hints of spice. Flavor not as spicy as I was hoping. It does have some fruity notes to it. Not all that bad, but nothing too special either.

Bottle Clear light-amber ale with a small, creamy, white head. The aromatics present clover honey, juniper berries, boiled pale malt and a sweet-smelling floral arrangement. Medium to full-bodied with a buttery mouthfeel and tickling carbonation.  Sweet clover honey and a mélange of evergreen, unidentifiable spices, flowers, miscellaneous herbs and a suggestion of mint in the flavor. Lightly sweet, honey and spice finish. Dries out just a touch. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!

Pours clear burnt orange with a small white head (smaller in a snifter than in my wifes NB glass).  Aroma of toast, pine, gin, orange, and toffee.  Flavor of caramel, toast, earthy hops, dirt, slight gin presence, and bitter orange.  Finish comes alive with the juniper tendancies being a bit more pronounced and a nice blend of earth and citrusy bitterness, biscuits, and spice.  Medium to light bodied, prickly but moderate carbonation, kinda boring mouthfeel.  Nonetheless, I enjoy the flavors pretty well, I just wish the texture and appearance were a bit bolder.

Bottle from Pacific Liquor: Created a thick foamy head which eventually retreated while the liquid was a straw gold color with evidence of sediment. As for the nose, the aroma is faint and very subdued considering this is a Lips of Faith series and it states that it was brewed with spices.  The flavor is earthy with an organic taste of barley malt, pine like hops, honey, and a touch of juniper berries. Overall, this doesnt hold a lot of spices to be tasted and is rather simple and ordinary.
Bottle (in NZ). Seemed to have a bit of everything without being much of anything. Quite quaffable for 7.2%.

(22oz bomber) clear amber, sparse bubbles. Nose of juniper, orange peel, Belgian yeast, funky. The juniper is hard to find though. Some graham cracker as well. Taste of toasty grain, spices, orange peel, lightly bitter. Soft carbonation, dry finish odd linger.

Bottle at NB.  Pours a clear nice amber with an ok head- slight dissipating.  Aroma is big on the dms, oxidation and baby diaper, juniper tips, berry mint earth leather.  Flavor is mint, dms, spice, earth, mint, spearmint, juniper berry, oxidation, too filtered too clean, too refined- with off components.  Meh.

Bottle...  Poured clear, pale-orange with a white head.  Nose had some spice with a whole lot of malt biscuitiness.  Creamy, full, well carbonated.  Slight malt sweetness, pine, floral, with a light yeasty tone.  Orange cream, vanilla, and malts returned in the finish.
Slightly hazy amber pour with a thin white head.  Aroma is piney, juniper berries and grains.  Citrus, spice,  and grassy hops.  Interesting
(bottle) light amber with almost no head. Spice and rye aroma. Flavor is floral hops, rye, juniper. Not overly spiced.

New Belgium misses the mark on one of my favorite traditional styles. This one is like a model. Gorgeous on the outside but somewhat shallow. Burnished copper with a thick pillowy white head and stick white frill lacing. Aroma of spruce, mint, honey, and flowers. Somewhat thin, starting soft on the mouthfeel, then rising carbonation delivers piny notes that tickle the tastebuds and scrape the tongue. Ends lightly sweet. Missing the malt backbone to carry the unique earthy notes forward.

Bomber.  Poured clear medium honeyed golden with a short, tight-bubbled off-white head.  The aroma picked up fresh, juicy juniper berries, blood orange, and a pinch of alcohol-based cleanser over a nondescript pale base.. floral notes showed as it warmed a bit, as well as citrus zest.. not bad, but I didnt particularly dig it.  The flavor opened with tart citrus, juniper, and oaky notes with sweeter honey rolling onto the middle.. peppery rye, more juniper, and a blend of less-identifiable spices around.. finished with an interesting interplay between dry spices and warm honey sweetness.  Medium-bodied with lower carbonation on the palate.. nice fresh, almost minty feel from the juniper.. not a great beer, but interesting.
Draught at Sycamore. I dont know where the Sahti is. This is mostly a slightly hoppy slightly sweet pale ale. Fine to drink, but nothing special.

22 oz. brown bottle. $5.99/ Central Market. San Antonio, TX. An orange colored beer with a small head. The aroma is grainy but also tangy, maybe even some citrus. Those three things blend together rather interestingly. The taste is caramel sweet at first then some grains but beyond that Im not finding much else. The alcohol is well hidden and is very easy going done. A rather boring beer.
A sweet alcohol malt aroma. Looks nice. Flavor is quite nice; zesty but not lemony. Some coating sugar but in a good way. A light tasty exploration away from the hoppy stuff Id had earlier that day.
Bottle.  Honey malt aroma with a hint of cinnamon.  Dark amber color with small head.  Sweet honey malt flavor with lightly bitter herbal finish.  Nicely drinkable.
Draft with Linh at Toronado San Diego. Pours an amber body with white head. Aroma is bready malts and fruit. Mouthfeel is smooth with notes of bread, malt, sugar, and tea.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle. Excited to try this one as it is only my second sahti.

The beer pours a golden-orange color with an off-white head. The aroma is heavy on the grain and spices, but I cant identify any of the individual notes. The flavor is a mix of pine (or is it juniper), grass, grain and spices. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not much going on here, one of the least exciting Lips of Faith beers.
Pretty color, looks like apple juice. Smells like flowery old ladies. Tastes like Citrus, cinnamon and rubbing alcohol. Bottle from Midtown Wine and Spirits, Nashville, TN

Aroma is of sugar and light perfume, rose water. flavor is honey, malt, and tea leaves. Really light, hard to believe this is 7.2 ABV. Kind of boring though.

Bottle from Midtown wine and Spirits, Nashville.
Clear orange brown pour with a light head.  Spicy aroma.  Light sweetness.  Malty with a very bitter finish.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a clear golden body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of juniper, florals, nuts, some citrus, and biscuit.  Flavor of grass, juniper, light citrus, and biscuit.

Bottle shared at the end of Pauls Thanksgiving weekend bash. Poured a mostly clear amber/orange body with a small white head. Aroma of  alcohol and lots of spice, cinnamon, all-spice, nutmeg and some grainy bread notes. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a spicey finish. Flavor is spicey with cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice and a touch of chocolate Not wowed by this one, average at best.

Mostly translucent, orange colored beer that looks easy and clean.  Aroma is sweet, a little spicy, with caramel present - light, but with a nice malt presence.  A very smooth, very easy, low density beer.  A good flavor, non-offensive, very sessionable, with caramel, biscuit, and spices.  Light malt, very lively mouth feel.
22 oz bottle. Low carbonation. Nose of alcohol. Very lacking in taste. Mild orange and very mild coriander. Was hoping for more out of this one!

22 oz bottle from Holiday Wine as I wait for my dumplings to finish steaming.  Im surprised by the low numbers on this one.  Orange with big bubbly head.  Not a big head, a head made of big bubbles that left quickly.  Nose is rather lagery with a high light fruit sharp sweetness.  Maybe the rye or the juniper berries.  Taste is mid sweet and oaky sharpness.  Alcohol.

On tap at the New Belgium Hub in the Denver International Airport. Cloudy bright orange-gold, very little head. Low aroma of fruit-kissed caramel and spices. Flavour is also surprisingly muted, with orange peel dominating, and soft spices accenting the finish. Pretty mellow little brew here, but not bad.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: bottle.  Pours clear golden orange with medium sized off white head.  Smell of new belgium malts - caramel, biscuit, toast, butter, with maybe a citrus aspect, orange peel.  Taste is the aforementioned malts, with an orange peel aspect, coriander, which intensifies slightly on the finish.  Medium bodied, very smooth, lightly spiced in spite of the bottle "ale brewed with spices."  Not a bad beer by any means, in fact its a good session, but for the price of the bomber a rip off.  This should be 7 or 8.99 a six pack.

Pours golden orange with aromas of caramel with dry fall leaves. Rosemary and caramel make and interestingly balanced palate, with a smooth and lingering finish. Not great, but interesting and very drinkable.
Bottle shared at Pauls tasting. Pours clear brown. Nose and taste of spice, tea, juniper leaves and toffee. Light malts. Medium body.

Bottle at Pauls tasting.  Pours a clear orange gold with a thin white head.  Weird spices and some juniper on the nose.  Medium bodied, spicy and malt.  Boring toast, spice and malt on the finish.  Rather boring.

Bomber into English pint. Pours a (mostly) bright copper with a small head that collapses pretty quick. Aroma is caramel malt with a hint of spruce and lemon peel, which become more pronounced as it warms. Taste is mostly sweet (sugary sweet but not cloying--at first anyway. Towards the bottom of the glass it gets tiresome) with a little bit of bitterness and sour. Flavor reminds me of Sprite mixed with beer. Highly carbonated with a medium to full body. Different. Im glad I tried it, but would probably never drink it again (unless it was free!).
This was a disappointing beer. I was looking forward to the spruce flavor, but theres not a lot going on here. Theres little more than a bit of caramel and toasted nuts. Its not bad, just boring.
This is  a disappointing lips of faith. Theres just not much to it. A light, slightly citric ale with a bit of juniper up front but that diminishes pretty quickly. OK, but not great.

Shared bottle.  Orange pour with a slim white head.  Juniper and rye nose with some earthy hops.  Medium body with a general sweetness, juniper, citrus notes and more rye.  Sweet sugary finish with banana and orange peel.
Lightly transparent amber, thin white head. Lightly sweet, tea and sugar, hot in the finish. Very bland and uninteresting and yet almost no balance despite the lack of anything strong.
Carbonated reddish brown with a thin almost white head.  Aroma of fruit, rye, juniper, and spices.  Taste is hoppy and citrus with savory bits of malt in the finish.
Bomber. Pours honey brown with cream head, some clings and rising bubbles. Malty, yeasty, slightly skunky aroma. Initial spicy, peppery taste fades quickly to malt. Thin palate.

Aroma:Juniper, a little clove and banana. Mild aroma.

Appearance:Dark honey or light amber in color. Low head.

Taste:Mild fruity flavors, including juniper, on the foretaste. The midtaste and aftertaste bring forward more caramel malty flavors. The Belgian yeast taste is also there.

Palate:Low body, good carbonation, a little astringency adds interesting textures to this beer. The malty caramel contribution to this beer coats the tongue a little.

Overall:This is a great sahti, subtle flavors and very refreshing.

A: The pour is a clear light golden-amber color with almost no head, just a few islands of white foam.

S: A slightly soured aroma with some hints of lemon. A decent amount of woodsy herbs and an interesting berry-like fruitiness. A fair amount of alcohol is noticeable as well.

T: Very woody, herbaceous, and "green". I dont really get the same fruitiness that I found on the nose. Sort of harsh and abrasive to the palate, especially with the high level of alcohol.

M: The body is medium with a fairly high level of carbonation.

D: This didnt seem all that "Sahti-like" to me. I think youre better off sticking to a more traditional example or at least the Nogne-O version.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden amber with a near white head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma has light fruits with some light grains with a bit of biscuit backing. Flavor is light with slightly tart light fruits with sweet grains and a bit of light citrus.

Sampled at the StlHops 3rd Anniversary Party.  This beer blurs the line between unique and odd.  Passion fruit dominated the flavor profile and then some kind of caramel.  I only wanted one sample of this.

ABR 2010.  Dry, herbal aroma.  Some malt, heavily carbonated.  There is a light bite on the palate that I do not recognize.  An unusual beer, and I will give any brewer credit for attempting a style like this.

Crystal clear copper with a slightly off-white head.  Not a lot in the aroma that I could find other than maltiness.  At first taste, it seemed to be a fairly normal pale ale.  After awhile, the spices started to show themselves, although honestly I couldnt definitely identify anything in particular.  Seemed to have a cardamom/ginger flavor but its very light.  Nice balance of malt and hops with a residual caramel sweetness and a light woodiness.  Very tasty, drinkable ale.

22oz bottle.pours a semi cloudy copper with a medium white head.Nose is heavy bread and chalky hops.Taste is really smooth with a great hop/malt balance.There is some obscure hops present as well as some spices.Great beer overall.

Draft at toad in the hole, in new belgium globe glass.

orangey gold. thin head that faded to a ring. slight sourness in smell. crisp. hint of funk. some flavors I cant place. interesting.

as it warms up, theres more hints of gym sock (or toe jam) and malt.

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Clear amber with dense medium head and abundant lace. Sweet aroma of Graham cracker, dust, rising dough, and... chicken coop?  Real funky stuff; light pepper, caramel, and earth. Nicely crisp finish aside from a touch of loamy pine or whatever it is.

Bomber from Brewforia. Pours a mostly clear copper into my New Belgium Globe with a large creamy white head. The aroma is sweet honey, flowers and pine. The flavor is nice and smooth; honey, cloves, dry caramel, toast, herbal and floral flavors. Enjoyable.

Clear orange pour, lots of visible bubbles, thin white head.  Subdued caramel, light spice, and juniper nose.  Moderate body on the sticky side with a lot of carb that makes it rather drinkable.  The flavor is not bad, but its overly sweet and caramelly for my taste.  Didnt detect much rye on the flavor, mostly its sweetness, iced tea, and a healthy amount of juniper as it finishes.  I did enjoy the juniper flavor, but this doesnt have a lot of complexity.
Tap.  The beer was interesting to say the least.  I noticed lots of rye, black tea, and some subtle juniper berries.  Earthy flavors and aromas.  Medium body that was easy to drink.

Brassy colored with poofy off-white head. Pleasing amber-malt accented aroma with pleasant wafts of hop leafyness, but no detectable juniper. The body has pitch-perfect malt backbone with simple, symphonic complexity and some mellowed baked wood character.

Sampled on 11/6/2010. Sampled on 11/6/2010. This traditional ale pours a medium copper orange color from a 22oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet, juniper and orange peel. A medium bodied traditional ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, caramel and bready. The hops are herbal and earthy. Hints of orange peel, rye and juniper. Lively carbonation. A touch on the sweet side and the flavors sometime dont match up well, but a very drinkable beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is slightly sweet.

Not alot of aroma and low in the foam department .. light in flavour besides tea leaves, wood, and bitters .. . goes down very smooth and is oddly enjoyable, but lacks any complexity, fun, or balls .. least exciting of all lips of faith series, but again, it went down to damn easy! high drinkability! .. ..Hell, I can get you a toe by 3 oclock this afternoon... with nail polish. These fucking amateurs...

Pours orange / amber with an off-white head.  The aroma has toasty dry caramel malt, woodiness, dry red fruits, hint of hops and some cream.  Medium lightly rough body that has some fullness and lightly sharp flowing carbonation.  The flavor starts like the aroma with a tree bark like trait that works for it.  There is also dry juniper and some spicy hops.  The finish is dry and has a liquor sort of taste, but no warmth or burn.  Interesting beer.
Dark golden with a creamy white head. Sweet honey and floral herbal aroma and taste with a tea like finish.

22 oz. bottle- Pours a orangish gold with a soapy white head , aroma is coriander and generic beer smell. The flavor is almost indescribable, better than expected, i taste spice, orange peel, odd. This is a cross between a Belgian wit and some spicy spice/herb/vegie beer, weird. Based on the reviews here I was not expecting much, but I was pleasantly suprised, very full body, creamy texture, somewhat oily, not bad really. Hard to pinpoint though.

On tap at Flying Saucer. Pours a cloudy amber with a small white head that leaves good sticky lacing. The aroma is a caramel malt. Medium mouthfeel with sweet malt and light hop. Easy to drink, a very good traditional ale from New Belgium.

650ml bottle from bev4less. Pours a translucent copper color with a small white head that soon vanishes. The aroma is weak and indistinct, its very tough to pick up any scent- save maybe a whiff of wet cardboard.  The taste is sweet malts with mild herbs. The palate is kinda weird--its watery and malty at the same time with prickly carbonation. Finishes short and clean. Overall: If this is a true sahti them Im not a fan of the style.

22 oz bottle. Pours a nice looking clear, deep gold with a off-white head. Aroma has some interesting fruit notes blended in with a light nuttiness and malt back bone. Flavor is very much the same with a light spiciness but seems a bit too sweet in the finish. Mouth feel is medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, its a nice solid brew but seems to be just too sweet, it seems to dominate over the added spices.

I had this on tap at Fountainhead in Chicago, IL while hanging out with my cousin.  It was a dark room so the appearance consisted of a pronounced white head, the ale looked golden and clear.  Aroma was pretty much a non-factor, taste of definite caramel malt and not much hops.  Honestly, it tasted like a more expensive Fat Tire.

(22oz bottle).  Pours clear copper with thin white head.  Carbonation is decent.  Aroma is of band-aid and is medicinal.  Not getting much of the juniper.  Taste is sweet with some maltiness. Light bodied with oily texture and slightly bitter, if non-descript, finish. Given the choice, I would select this over mega-produced beers, but it is a terrible disappointment otherwise.
Amber with an off-white head.  Rye, berries, bread, and alcohol aromas.  Rye, berry, and spicy fruit flavors.  Medium body with low carbonation.  Somewhat unusual flavors but not bad.

22oz bottle.  clear orange under small white head.  aroma is subtle with apple juice and white cake.  medium body.  not the most flavorful beer with the cake from the aroma and a really clean, short, fruitiness.  a mild flavored fruit, like honeydew.  quite dry.

Bottle.  Clear light amber pour, with small off-white head.  It has this strange sweet malty flavor, kinda like honey, but not exactly, juniper, lightly herbal, and a bit of spice.  Im not a big fan, but it is different.

Bomber poured a clear orange amber with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, fruittiness, juniper and light vanilla. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth drey finish. Flavors of carmel, juniper and light fruittiness with a smooth dry lingering carmel finish.
deep amber with a white head.  rye, ginger, honey, sweet malts, very herbal.  decent palate, honey, coriander, sweet overtone, not rich with rye.
Clear dark orange pour.  Light hops, light caramel aroma.  Flavor is lagerish, light hops, a bit watery with a creamy finish .  Mediocre.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2011 Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Aroma is mild and consists of hay and mild citrus. Taste is nice, a good amount of citrus and a light malty body. Nothing spectacular but pretty solid and easy to drink.... Had this again at a bar in draft form. It was still underwhelming to what I expected but not terrible. Very grainy and fruity.
Clear brown pour with medium white head. Aroma is spicy, juniper, grapes, brown sugar. Flavor is some cinnamon, juniper, brown sugar. Lightly carbonated.

Bottle, amber brown pour with tan foam, aroma of malty, brown sugar,
flavor is malty, cinnamon, spice, didnt really get any juniper or woody
notes, nice silky finish
Pours a dark golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with floral and citrus notes. Flavor is sweet, grainy, lemon and spices.

On tap @ Papago.  Pour was amber with an off-white head.  Im going to have to give this one another whirl.  My glass had absolutely no aroma, and barely started to show anything after it warmed.  For a brew made from barley and juniper, there should be some definate aromatics.  Nothing offensive, just nothing there.

Shared at Fall Gerryfest 2010. Very clear near amber body. Slightly off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, juniper, light lemon but somewhat thin for the ABV. Taste matches the aroma but adds light vanilla. Smooth light-medium body, alcohol fairly well contained. Decent but ultimately not great.

Sweet honey caramel nose, some sugar pine cones, hints of lemons.  Slightly hazy amber color, smallish head that dissipated quickly.  Juniper spice is mild, almost a malty gin tonic, balances towards the hops flavor.  Medium to heavy body, silky, med-high carbonation, finish is sweet with some spice poking through.  An enjoyable beer, not terribly hoppy in the traditional sense, the spicy may contribute to the perceived hoppiness, finish is clean and fresh.
Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Malt and light herbal aroma. Malt and salty flavor. Medium bodied. Malt and salt lingers with herbal notes.

On tap at Beveridge Place Pub in Seattle.  Poured a medium amber with dark dark overtones.  Aroma is of faint juniper, dark cola-like caramel, and very light spice.  No specific hop presence.  Tastes fairly sweet with low amount of carbonation adding to the syrupy mouthfeel.  Sweetness is more honeylike with very little if any "malty" toasty or bready flavors.  Presence of a rye-like spice but neither with enough variance or amount.  I did not enjoy this beer, but my girlfriend sure did!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 Tasted from a bomber purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Pours an orange-ish, clear body with a very light head.  Sweet, malty aroma.  Citrusy, somewhat tangy flavor.  Junipers create a hop-like flavor and bitterness. Somewhat interesting and actually doesnt really have an alcoholic flavor despite the 7.0% ABV.

Bomber. Pours a light golden amber with a small creamy white head. Aroma is sweet honey, grainy and mostly just malt with a slight light fruit accentuation. Flavor is again, very sweet and basically grainy with some more honey and sweet fruit though it is all very weak with the basic simple maltiness. A slight spice in the finish. Medium body and a fizzy carbonation. Pretty boring bland beer.
Bottle.  Plain amber color.  Aroma and taste of christmas wreath.  Not bad, but not exciting.

22oz. Poured a flat, clear orange with white bubbles dancing around. Aroma is cloyingly sweet already, artificial orange, cane syrup, candy cane, old Christmas candies moving as it warms to acetone and nail polish remover. Taste is metallic, syrupy sweet, cloying alcohol, medley of spices and things trying to grapple with a huge mess of an alcoholic concoction. Really the only notes I have here are "bleh!" and "Oh gross." Ive had Sahti before and this is not it.

22oz bottle, thanks BeerandBlues2.  Crystal clear amber body with small off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, juniper, light lemon.  Taste is moderately sweet, lemon, some juniper, cream, light vanilla.  Smooth light-medium body, alcohol fairly well contained.

Bottle (have also had a sample on tap). Pours with a clear, deep golden body with a lasting, fluffy khaki head. Strong lace that sticks. and fine bubbles. Aromas of rye, graham cracker, citrus, juniper, grass, bitterness, and rubbing alcohol. Flavors of rye, vanilla, banana (estery), graham cracker, alcohol, and biscuits. Lightly citrusy. Some noticeable alcohol warming for 7.2%. Lively/creamy carbonation. A pretty decent beer, but not as spiced as the few other Sahti inspired beers that I have had. 

Kind of confused by the other ratings/scores. My bomber poured completely clear, with strong carbonation and a lasting head. Maybe there is a bit of bottle variation.

On draft at the Happy Gnome. Pale amber in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are strongly floral, along with faint spicy rye and dried fruit. The rye element is stronger in the mouth, along with some dour under-ripe orchard fruit, mild citrusy hops, and vanilla cookie dough. Very heavy and slick mouthfeel... almost gummy. Pretty much no juniper that I could detect. Average at best.

Bottle.  Pours clear orange with a small, fizzy white head, light lacing with low retention.  Aroma is medium malt (straw, caramel, toast), light hops (earthy), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of juniper and flowers.  Flavor is medium malt (straw, caramel, toast), light hops (earthy), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of juniper, pepper, and flowers.  Medium body and carbonation, light warmth and creaminess with a spicy and dry finish.

10/22/10. Bomber.  Very clear light amber pour with a small fizzy white head thats gone fast.  Sweet herbal aroma that hints at juniper but mostly reminds me of boozey mint and nail polish remover.  Sweet caramelly and malty flavor that is faintly herbal and minty with dashes of metal and honey.  A bit odd, not great, not terrible.

Bomber from Whole Foods, Raleigh. Not having a terrific amount of experience with Sahtis, nor much confidence in the Lips of Faith series beyond a few exceptional beers, I was really unsure of what to expect here. First thing I noticed on the dingy brown pour were underwhelming carbonation and a thinnish look to the beer. Seems like some consistency issues, as other rates have noted a lively body. Spice in the nose is sharp but indistinct. To what tradition does this beer belong? Body is indeed thin, with only faint prickles detectable. Spice profile seems on auto-pilot, with weird mix of juniper, caramel malt, dried fruit, and light acidity. I have no idea what the goals were in brewing this beer, nor - shudder - if they were achieved. I found it a train wreck.

Draught.  Poured pale gold with a small head.  Aroma, to me, was juniper and not much else.   Sweet juniper flavour, tasted like Christmas candy.   Finish was like bad gin.  Sorry New Belgium, Finnish is not your line.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Cola-ish nose with lots of flowers and herbs, some honey malt. Taste is moderately sweet, lots of herbs, fresh flowers, lots of caramel.

Tap at Flying Saucer, Houston.Pours a rich, cloudy light amber with lively carbonation.  Nose is light peach and woodsy fruits.  Light touch of grass and sweetened leaves.  Flavor is blunt peach quicklyoffset by juniper, strawberry, cotton candy, and sugar cookie dough.  Semi-chalky finish but still smooth on the tongue.  Pleasant and refreshing.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours a golden color with minimal foam. After trying Dogfishs rendition of this traditional ale, this one just didnt stand up. The flavors mingled well, but there wasnt a lot of flavor from any of them. The rye was vaguely apparent, as were the juniper berries, but the other spices were lost on me. A decent beer, but considering what it was trying to be, I was disappointed.

The pour is a sparkling clear, orange color with a white, frothy, average head which does leave a thin layer of froth and tight, frothy lace.  The nose is certainly spicy with rye bread, pepper, allspice, rustic twig notes, and a bit of citrus peel.  The flavor is similar with more sweet notes emerging, some cookie, cinnamon and nutmeg, similar rustic twig notes, pink grapefruit peel, and honeyed rye bread notes.  The palate is nice with a nearly full body, soft to lively carbonation, and a creamy/round mouthfeel.  The finish is fairly short for the ABV, quite bready, and still spicy with pepper and cinnamon.  This is a pleasant beer with some of the characteristics of the more traditional sahtis, but lacked in a few major areas; the Belgian yeast notes and phenols were not there to add to the spicy nature and the juniper notes were quite subtle.  Not that I am any expert on the style, but this seemed like a fairly bland, American attempt at a very unique beer.  Not bad by any means but nothing compared to better examples I have tried.

I was very afraid of this beer going in. Having had the privilege of having a true, fresh Sahti, I was worried that NB would screw this up. Is it like a true Sahti? Barely even close, though the juniper is nearly right. Otherwise, this is no Sahti, but rather, a very nicely flavored ale that serves the Lip of Faith well. Just be certain. That this is, in no way, what a real Finnish Sahti tastes like.

Pours a clear copper with a thin off-white head. Mild aroma of malt, spices, and biscuits. Flavor is toasty yet sweet with hints of malt, biscuits, spices, pepper, and some fruit. Light body with medium carbonation. Interesting but not great.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA 
Aroma  Nice malt and hops aroma.  Floral and fruity.  
Appearance  Dark golden in color, Clear, with a thin head.   
Flavor  Nice malt flavor and floral and fruit flavors.  Hops gave this a great taste. 
Palate  Nice Dry finish with a Good Mouthfeel. 
Overall  Very nice drinking Ale.  Finished quite well.  Liked this beer.

On Tap at Brewforia in Meridian, ID.   Light orange with a full off-white head.  Pennant and light mild hop er juniper aroma.  Glad the juniper is nor over the top. Basically a pale ale with the bitterness a bit soft and a light malty body.   Pleasant but not very interesting.

22 oz from "Habits" in S.Salem ( they are getting better beers again).
Huge frothy overwhelmig head..cream coloured and very thick. When it dies down a bit i see a clear orange beer.
Aroma slightly subdued reallyFloral, vaguelly spruce tip, sight hint of toffee.
Taste..smooth toffee, pear,grassy hop and a nice hint of juniper right at the very end.
Ok on the palate..nothing mind bending.
Not sure about this one at all..is this Sahti?
No idea never had a real one before.

A solid pour into my produces a two-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head in my 25cl tulip glass.  The beer is a light amber hue that shows an almost brilliantly clear, bright copper / red color when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of cascade hops, ample biscuit like malt character, some spicy grain notes, lots of grapefruit, some lychee like aromas and some light juicy fruit gum like notes.  I dont really notice the juniper, but I think that it is mixing in with the fruity hop notes and does seem to add a touch of spicy berry character to the more dominant fruit character.  This smells like a nice hoppy ale, but I was hoping for more of the Sahti character coming through; other than this disappointment though this is quite a nice smelling beer.

Somewhat lighter than I was expecting and the beer has a cleaness that I associate with a bit too aggressive filtration process.  Flavors of tangerine, lychee and ruby-red grapefruit are balanced by an almost turpene like spiciness towards the finish that seems to be from the juniper.  This beer is fairly sweet, actually perhaps a bit too sweet in that it could use more hops or spice character to balance the sweetness.  The body definitely has a fullness to it that keeps this from being quaffable.  There is some nice backing malt character here that has a touch of spiciness to it, some toasty whole grain like notes, lots of lingering biscuit like character, and some caramelized-honey like malt sweetness.

Interesting perhaps, but not with the Sahti character that I was hoping for.  I cant help but feel a bit disappointed as the hops seem to dominate this beer.  I cant even just fully enjoy this as a hoppy beer as it comes off as being overly filtered and lacking in malt / hop complexity because of it.

Bomber. Pours copper with a foamy off-white head. Mixed spice aroma. Med. body/sharpish carb. Flavor is a melange of spicy flavors. Grains of paradise? Chocolate? Its drinkable beer, but confusing to me. Finishes not sweet, and not really bitter either. Whatever the flavor is, at least it is strong.
Average amber pour. S mba ll head. Dirty sock aroma. Average, English pale ale taste. Malty, with a good hop balance. If you go for run of the mill, then go for this. Old book finish, but not really.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (cereal, dog food), lightly hoppy (apricot), with notes of dish rag / detergent, orange, sugar, medicine.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Ugh.  Awful malt character and dirty/soapy odors all but ruin the aroma, and the only hint of juniper comes in a rather medicinal format rather than smelling like fresh evergreen.  Clumsy and embarrassing.

Pours a golden brown, almost an orange color with a very small head. The beer falls flat fairly quickly. The aroma is malty with some rotting leaf and mild spiciness. The flavor has some rich maltiness and a bit of spicy, piney, and bitter notes. The palate is surprisingly nice and lively given how flat the beer looks in the glass.

Bottle: Pours a clear bronze color with a nice white head. The nose is spicy and sweet, lots of juniper and citrus, creamy caramel and some sweet sticky honey. The flavor is a bit cloying, maybe needs a bit more hops. Im surprised to see this has hops in the first place, which arent really countering the sweetness at all. Finishes spicy, a little lingering but its easy drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2010 Draft. Pours a thin off white head, with some lacing, over a clear, light amber (SRM 6) body....nose is light biscuit, toast, toffee....taste is very light toffee, biscuit, finishing with light pepper, and light hop bitterness.....mouth feel is light, and slightly sweet, carbonation low. This is a pleasant, not overly strong beer, whose  finish is somewhat too sharp. BJCP 7//3/12/4/6
UPDATED: JUN 6, 2013 draft. amber, clear. candy sugar juicy fruit pineapple nose, strongly phenolic and dirty. tastes like juniper and thyme with heavy sugar and heavy syrupiness. foul.

Pours a dark golden with a very little white head and few bubbles.  This beer has an aroma of sweet hops, but it is a bit thins smelling.  This tastes a bit like an IPA with a smidgen more body and flavor.  There is a bit of oak.  This beer is easy drinking, but probably not the best of the Lips of Faith series.

Sweet raw sugar herbal nose of basil and juniper.  Clear caramel, persistent wet white head.  Sugary sweet again, hint of spice.  Touched where I expect a stronger presence.  Little iced tea.  Finishes with the juniper note up a bit, but really drinks more like a gently spiced amber.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper gold with a medium creamy white head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is bready malts and a little spice.

The flavor is bready malts and some rye and juniper with a decent sized hop finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied and creamy.

Overall, not a lot going on.  Its interesting to try a different traditional style, but sounds like they didnt really hit the style just like their Berliner Weisse (at least that one was more interesting).

Very clear pours - looks like iced tea - I should have known New Belgium would fuck this up and make a boring version of this style - it is arguable that they even really made a sahti here, as the dominant character aside from the malt are the hops - most beers Ive had in this or similar styles are explosions of earthy complexity, sometimes great, sometimes not so great, but at the very least interesting - smells like caramel, bread dough, a slight hint of juniper, toasted grains, hops, a light mint character - maybe, just maybe a hint of banana phenols in there - flavor is mostly malt sweetness, with some caramel and toasted grains - juniper is nowhere to be found - neither are any of the other earthy or smoky qualities you might expect - finish is hop bitterness and a light, indistinguishable spiciness - really one-dimensional and boring.

Tap at brewery. Not much on nose but just a hint of juniper. Really lacking in aroma. Poured golden amber, decent head. Flavor has notes of orange peel, juniper, and earthy bitterness, lightly sweet malt. Rather uninteresting really.

Bottle from the brewery. Copper color with a moderate head. Mild rye aroma.  Cant really smell juniper or smoke.  Flavor was mostly rye and moderate hops.  Could not really pick out the juniper.  Not very traditional.  Good beer, but didnt seem to fit the style. I was disappointed since this beer is part of my heritage.

Bottle.  Poured a clear golden-copper color with a half inch thick off-white head that receded to a ring and left some thin rings of lacing.  Aroma of light caramel, rye, honey, some earthy juniper, orange flesh, and some light alcohol.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry with some rye graininess and light undertones of lemon tartness that leads into a moderate juniper earthiness that transitions into a light, dry Amarillo hoppiness with some soft orange flesh that lingers into the finish with some light undertones of caramel.  Light carbonation a moderate, balanced mouth feel.  Overall, it seems like a decent brew, but more like a hoppy rye ale than a sahti.  The juniper is all but overshadowed by the hops in the flavor, and the traditional elements seem to get a bit lost.  Solid brew, but not what I was hoping for.

Live rate at the brewery!  Crystal clear 14 karat pour with a small ivory head that left a bit of lacing.  Aroma of malt, caramel, and honey.  Focus is also fairly sweet and definitely malt driven with a faint indication of juniper and spice.  Medium mouthfeel...a little creamy.  Not a bad brew.
